<summary>

1. The paper discusses the mechanical behavior of living cells, which is characterized as a viscoelastic body. The authors aim to extend the viscoelastic model to situations involving inelastic deformations, and they introduce a reversible inelastic version of the model.
2. The model exhibits strain / stress stiffening, fluidization, and cyclic softening, and it can accommodate for the active biological remodeling in living cells and tissues.
3. The authors review some basic facts about the wormlike chain model, introduce their extended reversible inelastic version, and discuss the physical mechanism underlying the mechanical response under pulsed and periodically pulsed loading.
4. The model exhibits the hallmarks of nonlinear cell mechanics, including strain / stress stiffening, fluidization, and cyclic softening, and it can be used to subject the underlying physical picture to a more stringent test than hitherto possible by comparing its predictions to dedicated experiments.
</summary>

6. The preferred embodiment of the invention includes a housing with an upper and lower portion, a delayed urging means, and an interface member.
7. The delayed urging means is fastened to the bottom of the interface member and is made of a material that exhibits a delayed rebound after being compressed.
8. The device is designed to securely hold the ball and tee into the device when placed below the interface member and the tee is slid into the slot.
9. The dimensions of the device, including the height, interface member size, slot dimensions, and delayed urging means size, affect the performance of the device.
10. The device can be attached to a golf club grip and used to retrieve the tee once the ball has been hit.
</summary>

1. The invention relates to a novel sanitizable rotary valve that may be used in conjunction with liquid chromatography and other processes.

3. The valve includes a rotor with a thermoplastic elastomeric diaphragm integrally molded to form multiple sealing ports, and a stator with ports or grooves that sealably engage the diaphragm to form sanitary elastomeric tubular ducts.

The invention also includes means for at least one SIP/barrier gutter located on an inner surface of the valve, orthogonal actuating means for incrementally adjusting the rotor perpendicular to its direction of linear motion, and fluid connection means for fluidly connecting stator and rotor connection ports to externally located fluid sources and separation means.

The invention provides an apparatus for continuous electrolytic coloring of an aluminum strip or wire comprising a means for continuously supplying an aluminum strip or wire, an anodic oxidation bath for anodizing the aluminum strip or wire and having a cathode disposed therein, an electrolytic coloring bath for electrolytically coloring the anodized aluminum strip or wire, and an electric circuit for connecting the cathode and the anode to a power source without connecting the aluminum strip or wire directly to a power source.

2. The method involves measuring the entire momentary quantity of each fiber lot prior to the first pass or prior to each pass of the bale opener, calculating a partial quantity that corresponds to a predetermined proportion of the momentary entire quantity, and removing the partial quantity from the fiber bale continuously.
3. The partial quantity is determined anew for each fiber bale, and if instead of the determined partial quantity, a larger or smaller partial quantity is removed, the deviation can be corrected during the next pass.
4. The method is particularly adapted for making mixtures of throughout constant quantity proportions, and the bale opener removes fiber material from each fiber lot until the intended quantity is reached.
5. The apparatus includes a bale opener for removing fibers from the various stored fiber lots, as well as a quantity measuring device associated with the opener and a control device that controls the mode of operation of the opener.
6. The quantity measuring device may be a height-measuring arrangement that effects a simple and accurate determination of the partial fiber quantities to be removed from the bales.
7. The control device has a control apparatus and a computer, and the control arrangement determines the precise partial quantities to be removed and controls the fiber removing operation.
8. The control apparatus has additional functions, such as controlling the beginning and end of the bale opening operation regarding the removal of the partial fiber quantity, and the drive of the bale opener is a pole-reversible electromotor that accelerates the operation of the bale opener if necessary.

7. The use of the rake system in conjunction with the slowing of the movement of the yarn carrying means near the extremities of travel achieves parallelism of successive courses.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to an arrangement for controlling thread tension in a spool creel.
2. The invention provides an arrangement for controlling tension of threads in a spool creel having a plurality of spool holders.
3. The arrangement includes a plurality of controllers, each coupled to a different corresponding spool holder.
4. The controllers are simultaneously settable by fluid pressure.

9. The biasing arrangement operates by fluid pressure and is connected to the tensioning lever.

1. The present invention relates to a sewing machine detector that detects the position of a sewing needle and the speed of the sewing machine.
2. The detector includes a shaft connected to the sewing machine shaft, and a plurality of light shielding discs mounted coaxially on the shaft.
3. The first light shielding disc detects the sewing machine speed and a needle UP position, while the second light shielding disc detects a needle DOWN position.
4. The base material of the light shielding discs is made of a light-transmitting synthetic resin, and the discs are provided with light shielding areas and indicators.
5. The detector also includes a module section connected to a control circuit section, which includes electronic parts such as light emitting and receiving devices and a signal processing circuit.
6. The light shielding discs are designed to withstand constant vibration during the operation of the sewing machine, and the shaft supporting the discs is made of a material with low thermal expansion.
7. The detector is durable despite the detrimental effects of vibration, and the optical fibers are only employed for detection purposes.
8. The detector includes a thinner and more compact detecting section, and the curvature of the optical fibers is minimized to reduce stress imposed on the fibers.
9. The power indicating light does not electrically interfere with the operation of the detector and controller, and the module section is provided with a connector for electrical connection to the control circuit section.
10. The present invention overcomes the disadvantages of conventional apparatus and provides a low-price detector for a sewing machine that is durable and includes a thinner and more compact detecting section.

1. The process of the invention comprises partial coagulation and drawing, completion of the coagulation, washing under specified conditions, drying, and possibly finishing.

5. The invention produces a finished yarn having a high degree of white through the processing stages of partial coagulation and drawing, completion of the coagulation, washing under specified conditions, drying, and possibly finishing.
6. The traditional process requires handling, separating, and recovering a higher number of treatment liquors, which implies an economical burden compared to the process according to the invention.

<summary>
1. The inventors of the patent decided that a small deaeration tank was needed for oxygen bleached pulp to be deaerated before washing.
2. The tank should be able to handle pulp at a consistency of 1-5% and have an exterior diameter the same as the oxygen reactor.
3. The tank should be a cylindrical tank with an open top and a flat bottom, and its exterior height should be between 1 and 337 times the diameter of the tank.
4. The inlet pipe of the tank should be located between the upper surface of the slurry and the top edge of the tank, and it should allow the pulp to enter the tank above the surface of the slurry.
5. The outlet of the tank should be located in the bottom plate of the tank and should be sized to handle the amount of pulp leaving the tank.
6. The tank may be closed and be a pressure or vacuum tank, and it will be closed if the oxygen or steam is being recovered.
7. The tank should be built to withstand pressures of ±1 atmosphere.
8. The height of the slurry in the tank should be controlled by a height sensor at the bottom of the tank.
9. The deaeration tank is shown in FIGS. 1-4, and its exterior diameter is typically between 0.75 and 1.5 times the diameter of the tank.
</summary>

2. The bedroom cabinet is composed of a hexahedron formed by four side surfaces, an upper surface, and a lower surface, and an outer casing and an inner casing.
3. The outer casing is formed by an upper outer casing and a lower outer casing, while the inner casing is formed by a front surface panel, a back panel, left and right side panels, a ceiling panel, and a bottom panel.
4. The bedroom cabinet has an upper surface portion, a back surface portion, left and right side surfaces, and a front portion, with the front portion having a notch portion corresponding to the upper half of an exit.

The lower outer casing has a front surface portion formed with a notch portion corresponding to the lower half of the exit, and the upper outer casing and the lower outer casing are assembled in such a way that the flange of the upper outer casing is brought into abutment with the flange of the lower outer casing.
6. The present invention further provides a bedroom cabinet wherein a clearance between an outer casing and an inner casing is formed over the whole periphery, and spacer members are interposed in the clearance in a suitably spaced relation.
7. The spacer member is formed with a venting groove, and an uniform air flow passage is formed in the outer periphery of the inner casing, allowing for smooth natural ventilation within a room and increasing the sound-proofing effect.
8. The bedroom cabinet can be closed stacked or installed adjacent to each other, and the clearance between the outer casing and the inner casing can house therein wirings or the like for interior electric devices.
9. The bedroom cabinet is of the dual construction, consisting of the outer casing and the inner casing, and is excellent in mechanical strength.
10. The present invention provides a further embodiment of the bedroom cabinet, wherein a part of the spacer is formed with a venting groove, allowing for smooth natural ventilation within a room and increasing the sound-proofing effect.

1. The present invention relates to a floor transport system for use in a fluid treatment chamber.
2. The system is designed to transport wheeled hand trucks into and out of the chamber without contaminating the sanitary environment.
3. The invention provides an enclosed floor track system for use in a fluid treatment chamber.
4. The system includes wheel channels into which the wheels of the truck roll and are disposed above the fluid level on the floor by support legs.
5. The wheel channels include opposed sidewalls, one of which extends upwardly more than the other.
6. The vertical space between the shorter sidewall and the cover plate above it accommodates the axle structure connecting the truck frame to the wheel.
7. The cover plate may be connected to the longer sidewall by a hinge so that it can be pivoted away from the wheel channel and thereby facilitate the cleaning of the channel.
8. The enclosed floor track system is structured to accommodate trucks with downwardly depending struts supporting the wheel structure.
9. The sidewalls of the wheel channel extend upwardly beyond the top of the wheel structure and include at the top edges thereof inflatable elastomer seals.
10. The seals are hose-like and are attached along the length of the sidewall top edges so as to enclose around the hand truck wheel struts and prevent entry of the brine solution into the guide track.

2. The lock device includes an engaging member provided on one of the boom and a boom bracket, and an engaged member provided on the other of the boom and the boom bracket.
3. The engaging member is constituted by a plate formed on one side thereof with a hook part, and on the other side thereof with a slot.
4. According to the present invention, the lock device is constructed easily, and by sliding the engaging member along the slot and by touching the guide member with either the first or second surface of the engaging member, the engaging member can be held in the lock position or the lock release position.
</summary>

<summary>

2. The device comprises a horizontally extending platform with a central portion, longitudinally extending edges, and longitudinally spaced end portions, each having an opening therethrough.
3. The device also includes a first roller assembly connected to the platform proximate each end portion, with each roller assembly comprising at least two rollers adapted to maintain the end portions of the platform in a spaced relationship with respect to the bottom of the swimming pool.
4. The device further comprises a roller construction disposed on either side of the opening in the central portion of the platform, with each roller construction including a housing connected to the platform having spaced apart walls and a pair of axles received within the vertical slots for rotatably carrying a pair of rollers for rotation about the axle between the end portions of the spaced apart walls.

1. The present invention relates to oil well drilling tools and apparatuses.
2. The invention provides a retrieving tool that is removably securable on the exterior surface of a sub-unit.
3. The apparatus of the present invention includes a sub-unit having a mandrel with a longitudinal bore therethrough and a retriever section with a bore for fitting around the mandrel.
4. The retriever section is adapted with means for engaging with an extended J-slot of a wear bushing.
5. The apparatus also includes groove portions along the exterior surface of the mandrel, which slidably accommodate insertion members on the inner wall of the retriever section.
6. During the drilling process, the drill string is set within interior casing, and the upper most end of the casing head is connected at the well head area.
7. Above the well head, a blow-out preventer stack is positioned, and it is critical that the rotation of the drill pipe does not make contact with the surfaces in the well head area.
8. To prevent this possible contact, a wear bushing or collar is positioned in the area between the drill pipe and the well head.
9. The wear bushing takes the wear as the drill pipe is rotated during the drilling process, and it is essential to retrieve the wear bushing when the drill bit is withdrawn from the hole.
10. The apparatus of the present invention provides a simple and straightforward manner to retrieve the wear bushing, and it is removably securable on the exterior surface of the sub-unit.

3. Within the outer body is a passage that is in fluid communication with the passage in the string, and pressure can be delivered from the surface to lateral ports through the passage.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to systems and methods for producing or delivering heat at or near the down hole end of production tubing of a producing oil or gas well for improving production.
2. The present invention addresses two primary shortcomings of conventional down hole heating systems: (1) the heat is not properly focused where it needs to be, and (2) existing systems fail due to design elements that are not protective of electrical components from chemical or physical attack.
3. The present invention provides a down hole heating system for use with oil and gas wells that exhibit less than optimally achievable flow rates due to high oil viscosity and/or blockage by paraffin.
4. The system includes a heating unit with electrical resistance type heater rods, cables that supply the current, and heat insulating packer and stainless steel collars to contain the heat.
5. The present invention also addresses the problem of physical and chemical attack of the electrical connections between the power leads and the heater rods of conventional heating systems.
6. The summary highlights the key features of the invention, including the focus on improving production by delivering heat at the down hole end of production tubing, addressing the shortcomings of conventional systems, and providing a protective design for the electrical connections.

<summary>

2. The tool has an external pull tool or overshot that can be used in well servicing operations or an internal pull tool or spear.
3. The tool is adapted to be provided on a wire line controlled pulling tool and run into the well casing or well bore for establishing a mechanical connection with an object positioned in the well bore.
4. The tool has a catch mechanism that can be locked and unlocked, depending on the relative positions of the inner and outer body structures, to disconnect the pulling tool from the down hole object.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to sensors, and in particular to position and motion sensors.
2. Many mechanical systems contain moving parts not directly linked through mechanical means whose position, timing, or speed must be monitored and controlled with correction schemes for safe or efficient operation.
3. The present invention is directed to sensing position or movement of an object.
4. A position sensor signal conditioner and remotely electrically connected sensor monitoring equipment provide a method of multiplexing multiple sensors on a minimum number of wires with a minimum of energy required from each sensor monitoring system.
5. One embodiment of the invention is herein described as a sensor that may comprise a waveform generator and an error correction generator for modifying a sensing signal by removing unneeded power and providing the signal to a remote monitor via two wires useful in multiplexing multiple sensors.
6. The error correction generator determines and eliminates strong static signals and error signals that do not deliver information about a position of an object being sensed, wherein inclusion of the static and error signals would require energy.
7. One embodiment may include a digitally stored offset and error correction closed-loop compensation circuit for constantly comparing a value of the conditioned sensing signal to a desired minimum value and generates a correction signal that is subtracted from the offset and error signal to deliver a sensor signal output that is close to a desired minimum value.
8. The constant comparing of the sensor signal output to the desired minimum value proceeds in a first direction relative to a direction of sensor output signals generated when an object being sensed moves in a relatively slow manner compared to a nominal speed of objects being monitored such that signals are generated as the objects move are not subtracted from the sensor output to a degree significant enough to cause significant variance between a position of the object and a signal level delivered by the sensor indicating the position.
9. Further, the constant comparing of the sensor signal output to the desired minimum proceeds in a second direction relative to the direction of signals generated when the object being monitored moves in a relatively fast manner compared to the speed of objects being monitored so signals generated by errors or from other noise sources are subtracted from the sensor output in a manner sufficient to allow for a deletion of these error or static signals from being a significant portion of the position signal generated by the sensor.
10.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a valve actuation system for internal combustion engines, particularly in automobiles.
2. The system aims to reduce gas consumption by efficiently and effectively controlling valve port openness, in conjunction with the engine's performance requirements.
3. The invention provides a simple, robust, and infinitely variable valve actuator that is easy to operate and provides precise control over valve position.
4. The system uses a rotating cam and translating means to interact with a controllable actuating means, which controls valve position and displacement.
5. The valve actuator system can be computer-controlled to operate any set of pistons, allowing for variable valve displacement and minimal fuel consumption.
6. The invention also provides for the possibility of multiple controllers for each cylinder, offering greater flexibility and control over the engine's performance.
7. The system's kinematics are designed to provide smooth, sensitive control over the engine's performance, resulting in improved fuel economy and reduced emissions.
8. The valve actuation system of the present invention offers a significant improvement over traditional spring-based valve actuation systems, providing a more efficient and environmentally friendly solution for internal combustion engines.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for a fluid-flow machine, particularly a gas turbine.
2. The invention provides a simple and efficient solution to the problem of cooling hot gas flow in a fluid-flow machine.
3. The invention involves using separate inserts instead of casting the separating walls in the blade.
4. The inserts are composed of metal or non-metal materials and are inserted through the blade root or tip.
5. The use of inserts eliminates the large amount of material in the transitional region between the hot-gas wall and the separating wall.
6. The invention also eliminates thermal stresses between the separating wall and the hot-gas wall.
7. The invention reduces the weight of the blade and thus the centrifugal-force stresses both in the blade root and in the blade airfoil section.
8. The invention provides a secure seating for the inserts by connecting them to the flow deflection apparatus using an integral material joint.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a system and method for controlling the operation of a fuel delivery system for a vehicle, such as a throttle valve.
2. The system comprises a control unit that receives a signal indicating accelerator pedal position and a signal indicating the position of the throttle valve, and provides an output signal to control a DC motor that automatically sets the throttle position for optimal performance of the vehicle.
3. The invention also provides for switching from automatic to manual control without causing the vehicle to lurch forward or stall, by smoothly switching between automatic and full manual control without any interruption in the operation of the vehicle.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to methods and apparatus for generating heat from particulate-laden gas or directly from waste fuels such as wood waste.
2. The invention provides a waste fuel burner that emits discharges of minimal quantities of particulate materials within local environmental regulation limits.
3. The burner includes a primary combustion chamber with a refractory lining, fuel feed system, and air supply system.
4. The primary chamber gases are directed through a horizontal, disc-shaped flame holder into a secondary combustion chamber.
5. The secondary chamber has a plurality of adjustable tuyeres for introducing secondary combustion air.
6. The volatile gases are directed around the flame holder and into the secondary chamber, where they are mixed with excess air and combusted.
7. The flame holder serves as a barrier to prevent particulate matter from entering the secondary chamber.
8. The secondary chamber is provided with a pressure isolator to isolate the primary chamber from secondary chamber combustion air.
9. The pressure isolator has radial vanes that destroy the angular momentum of the downward-spiraling secondary combustion air, minimizing its entry into the primary chamber.
10. The invention provides a unique aspect of adding the primary and secondary chambers to any source of dirty particulate-laden combustible gas and effectively burning the gas to provide a source of useful heat and remove particulate for meeting environmental emission standards.
</summary>

2. The invention provides a hybrid evaporative cooler system that incorporates components of a vapor compression refrigeration unit, providing a lower temperature but at higher energy levels, and a portion of the cooled useful air being diverted to mix with the working return air for countercurrent contact with the evaporating water.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to engine compression release brakes, specifically to those having a reduced number of components.
2. An engine includes an engine housing defining a plurality of engine cylinders, and an engine compression release brake is provided for each of a portion of the engine cylinders, which is less than all of the plurality of engine cylinders.
3. The engine compression release brake includes a brake body and an electrical actuator, where the electrical actuator is a solenoid that includes a biasing spring, a coil, and an armature.
4. The armature is attached to move with a valve member, and when the solenoid is de-energized, the valve member is biased toward its downward position by the biasing spring.
5. When the valve member is in this position, it opens a high pressure seat defined by the brake body and closes a low pressure seat.
6. Also positioned in the brake body is a spool valve member that is movable between an upward, retracted position and a downward, advanced position.
7. The spool valve member defines a high pressure annulus that is always open to a high pressure passage and is positioned such that it can open an actuation fluid passage to the high pressure passage when the spool valve member is in its advanced position.
8. A low pressure annulus is also provided on the spool valve member, which can connect the actuation fluid passage to a low pressure passage defined by the brake body when the spool valve member is in its retracted position.
9. When pressure communication passage is fluidly connected to a high pressure manifold, such as when the pilot valve member is in its downward position, pressure within the spool cavity is high and the spool valve member is preferably hydraulically balanced and maintained in its retracted position by the biasing spring.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to military weapons and simulators, specifically to a small arms firing effect simulator that provides realistic training without modifying the weapon.
2. The simulator uses an electro-mechanical pyrotechnic sound and flash simulator for use with small arms training, which can be installed in a firing unit that can be inserted into the weapon via the magazine breech.
3. The simulator produces sound and flash by electrical ignition of a pyrotechnic in a confined space and venting the combustion produced in a manner that utilizes the weapon's ejection port.
4. The invention provides a cost-effective means for simulating small arms fire noise and flash without dangerous pressuration of the ignition chamber.
5. The circuitry of the simulator consists of ten functional blocks, including a bolt interface, trigger interface, oscillator control, firing counter, firing decoder, firing sensors, and a MILES interface.
6. The simulator is packaged within a reusable housing that resembles a magazine clip for insertion into an M16 rifle, and includes an exhaust port designed for cooperation with the ejection port of the rifle.
7. The simulator provides a realistic simulation of operator actions during the firing of live rounds, and the firing sensor detects the firing of the weapon and resets the bolt flip-flop, which inhibits the 500 Hertz oscillator.
8. The firing counter and firing decoder count the pulses from the 500 Hertz oscillator and provide the firing signals to the pyrotechnic simulator.
9. The pyrotechnic simulator includes ten charges, each connected to a different SCR, and the firing of the weapon triggers the SCRs to fire the charges, producing the sound and flash of a real bullet firing.
10. The invention provides a reliable, low maintenance, and reusable small arms training device that can be used to train combat troops in a realistic and cost-effective manner.
</summary>

7. <summary>
1. The invention concerns the fabrication of plates or blanks of coated steel intended to be welded and then heat treated to obtain parts having good mechanical characteristics and good corrosion resistance.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields, particularly magnetic fields.
2. The system has two sensors for measuring the amplitude of the interfering field, and a control unit for calculating control signals for six coils based on the sensor signals.
3. The control unit is designed as a digital processor, such as a Digital Signal Processor (DSP) or a field-programmable gate array (FPGA), and receives the sensor signals as inputs.
</summary>

1. The system is designed to compensate for both homogeneous and inhomogeneous magnetic fields.
2. The control unit combines the sensor signals to create a virtual sensor with a 6x1 matrix of output signals.
3. The control unit uses an independent control loop for each of the three space axes, with a control algorithm that transforms the virtual input signals into changed signals.
4. The system uses a 6x6 matrix L to calculate the control signals from the changed input signals, and the algorithm is described by a matrix multiplication.
5. The more inhomogeneous the compensation field is, the smaller is the region around the feedback sensor with a good compensation effect.
6. If the interference field is inhomogeneous, it is not purposeful to generate a homogeneous compensation field, and a single actuator coil may be used instead of a pair of Helmholtz coils.
7. The control unit processes the two sensor signals to create a 6-vector S, which is then used to calculate the control signals.
8. The algorithm used by the control unit is overall described as L·Ω(M·S), where L is a 6x6 matrix, Ω is an operator, M is a 6x6 matrix, and S is a 6x1 matrix.
9. The system is designed to avoid interferences between two compensation systems operated directly beside each other, and a 6x6 feedback matrix C is used to describe the feedback between the control signals.
10. The system is suitable for use in a variety of applications, including scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and other imaging systems using magnetic fields.

1. The invention relates to a technique of easily and quickly determining the optimum value of feedback gain used for calculating correction amount in feedback control.
2. The method of determining feedback gain according to the invention comprises provisionally determining a predetermined value of a feedback gain, executing feedback control using the provisionally determined feedback gain, detecting an error between a designated value and an actual value of the subject of control during the execution of the second step, and calculating an evaluation value indicative of the character of feedback control according to the error detected in the third step.
3. The proportional gain is a factor which influences the stability of control, and the length of a curve obtained by plotting the error against time axis is suited for evaluating the proportional gain.
4. The integral gain is a factor influencing the accuracy of control, and the integral of the error reflects the accuracy of control, which is thus suited for evaluating the integral gain.
5. The differential gain is a factor influencing the response of control, and the integral of the absolute value of the error is suited for evaluating the differential gain.
6. The present invention will be more fully understood from the following detailed description and appended claims when taken with the accompanying drawings.
7. The method of determining feedback gain according to the invention can be applied to the running control of an AGV, and the construction of the AGV will be described with reference to FIG. 2.

<summary>
1. This invention relates to an improved apparatus for automatically spin checking a driven disc assembly.
2. The apparatus includes an enclosure having a stationary ring mounted thereon and a movable ring slidably supported thereon.
3. A torque motor is provided with an output shaft connected to a splined hub, upon which the driven disc assembly is mounted for rotation between the two rings.
4. Means are provided for selectively moving the movable ring toward the stationary ring so as to frictionally engage the driven disc assembly therebetween.
5. When so engaged, the distance separating the two rings is measured by an electronic sensor.
6. The torque motor is then energized to exert a predetermined torque on the driven disc assembly, attempting to rotate it against the frictional force generated by the rings.
7. Means are provided for sensing this rotation and for measuring the distance separating the two rings at that time.
8. The difference between these two distances is compared with a standard value to determine if the driven disc assembly is excessively warped.
9. The apparatus operates automatically without manual involvement by an operator and generates an external indication to the operator of the test results.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention is a system for reducing or eliminating undersea optical repeaters in a trunk and branch ring network by replacing repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers.
2. The invention utilizes the branch fiber optic cable, which carries communications signals, to transmit optical energy at a wavelength other than that of signal wavelength to the remote optical amplifier.
3. The optical energy is used as a power source for an optical amplifier, which is located in the branch fiber optic cable, the optical fiber cable trunk, or the branching unit.
4. The invention has several advantages, including (i) a single optical fiber cable trunk cut maintains full connectivity along the trunk and to all cable stations via their respective branch fiber optic cables; (ii) branch fiber optic cable cuts isolate the associated cable station without compromising ring integrity; (iii) the network respects sovereignty concerns that often arise in undersea communications networks; (iv) the network can accommodate reconfigurable wavelength add/drop branching units; and (v) the use of repeaterless technology can reduce capital costs and operating and maintenance costs of communications networks.
5. The invention is particularly well suited for undersea applications of repeaterless trunk and branch wavelength-division-multiplexing (WDM) optical fiber communications ring networks, but can also be applied to other methods of signal multiplexing and terrestrial communications systems.
6. The invention consists of a trunk and branch fiber optic ring network, which includes four branch assemblies, a hub assembly with remote pumping, and a hub assembly without remote pumping, coupled by an optical fiber cable trunk and configured in a ring topology.
7. The hub assembly with remote pumping includes a hub coupled to both ends of the optical fiber cable trunk, a light emitting power source coupled to the hub, and an optical amplifier located in the branch fiber optic cable, the optical fiber cable trunk, or the branching unit.
</summary>

6. The foil electron multiplier can be used in photomultiplier tubes and particle detectors.
7. The foil electron multiplier can be arranged collinearly or in an array along an arc.
8. The anode is electrically connected to sensing electronics that measure the output charge or current deposited onto the anode.
9. The foil electron multiplier can span a large active area, allowing for position-sensitive anode.
10. The foil electron multiplier can be used to detect particles such as electrons, ions, and photons.

4. Images from a television set or a movie screen appear three-dimensional when viewed through the frame with both eyes open.
5. The Pulfrich effect is caused by the difference in the time it takes for light to travel through a dark lens than through a clear lens.
6. The invention uses a computer algorithm running on a computer processor contained within the 3-D Phenomenoscope to calculate in real-time and from a multiplicity of media frames, the synchronization and control events.
7. The 3-dimensional visual effect is produced regardless of whether the motion picture was shot on regular or digital film, or whether the presentation media is film, digital film, VCR tape, or DVD.
8. The invention allows any motion picture with a degree of sustained lateral motion (for instance, every 'chase' sequence) to be viewed with the visual effect of 3-dimensions.
9. The human eye can sense and interpret electromagnetic radiation in the wavelengths of about 400 to 700 nanometers, and the invention uses this principle to create the 3-dimensional visual effect.
</summary>

The present invention relates to a field emission display panel or device, and more particularly to a field emission display device having at least one reduction plate or electrode which deflects ionic emission gas away from the field emission components of the device to prevent damage to the field emission components.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to devices for producing electrical power from surface waves.
2. The invention improves upon prior art devices by using a single gas-tight container submerged to a depth slightly below anticipated wave and swell troughs.
3. The container has a fixed depth rigid end or surface held at a relatively fixed depth relative to the water body mean water level or wave troughs.
4. A second movable rigid end or surface opposes the fixed end, separated and connected by a flexible, gas-tight, reinforced elastomer or flexible metal bellows or diaphragm.
5. Overhead waves and troughs produce hydrostatic pressure variations which compress and expand the container, expanding and contracting the movable end.
6. The container expansion and contraction is enhanced by partial evacuation of the container or venting of the container's gas to a floating surface atmospheric vent or to a floating surface expandable bellows or bladder.
7. The relative linear motion between the fixed and movable ends is connected to and transferred to a hydraulic or pneumatic pumping means or mechanical or electrical drive means.
8. The pressurized fluid flow from the hydraulic or pneumatic pumping means drives a motor or turbine with electric generator.
9. The invention improves upon prior art devices by using a single gas-tight container submerged to a depth slightly below anticipated wave and swell troughs.
10. The invention can produce 0.25 MW to 1 MW of electrical power with a typical diameter and stroke of 5-10 meters.
</summary>

<summary>
1. User fees are a way for the government to finance its activities by charging individuals or organizations for goods or services provided.
2. The distinction between a "fee" and a "tax" can be blurry, but generally, a fee is related to a specific benefit or service received from the government, while a tax is a broader form of revenue collection.
3. The beneficiary-pays principle is a guiding principle for implementing user fees, which suggests that the program or service should be funded primarily by those who benefit from it.
4. The amount of a fee should be set based on the cost of providing the service or benefit, and the extent to which the program benefits users or the general public.
5. User fees can promote economic efficiency by ensuring that resources are allocated to the most highly valued use, and can also act as a market test to encourage certain behaviors.
6. However, user fees can also run contrary to another facet of equity, the ability-to-pay principle, if they are proportionally more burdensome for low-income individuals.

6. The executive branch has agreed that the Take Care Clause does not provide the President with the authority to frustrate legal requirements imposed by law, and that the Clause imposes a duty on the President to ensure that executive branch officials obey Congress's commands.
7. In Kendall v. United States ex rel. Stokes (1869), the Supreme Court held that the President had no authority to direct a Postmaster General to violate a statutory obligation, as the duty and responsibility grew out of and were subject to the control of the law.
8. The Court rejected the government's assertion that the Take Care Clause constituted a source of presidential power, and instead held that the Clause could not be relied upon as a basis for noncompliance with the law.

7. The data also do not indicate whether the job loss is voluntary or involuntary, nor how many of the individuals who lose jobs also gain jobs.

3. Clinical assessment tools may not be sufficient for detecting ipsilateral motor deficits, but deficits in dexterous motor and coordination function on the ipsilateral side have been identified in laboratory testing (Boldface, para. 2).
4. Several possible mechanisms for ipsilateral motor deficits have been suggested, including disrupted counterbalance of each hemisphere, dysfunction of the uncrossed corticospinal track, or the different roles of both sides in hemispheric functions (Boldface, para. 6).
5. Ipsilateral sensory deficits related to proprioceptive sense have also been observed in stroke patients, and there is a negative correlation between motor and sensory deficits (Boldface, para. 8).
6. The primary sensory cortex (S1) conveys efferent projection to the posterior parietal cortex (Brodmann's area 5 and 7), which is connected bilaterally through the corpus callosum (Boldface, para. 9).
7. Disturbance of transcallosal transfer after unilateral brain damage may lead to ipsilateral sensory deficits (Boldface, para. 10).
8. The correlation between ipsilateral motor deficits and sensory deficits can be explained by the close relationship between sensory and motor function (Boldface, para. 11).
9. Future studies will be required to determine more detailed mechanisms of other movement and sensory deficits, other than proprioceptive sense, in the ipsilateral upper limb of patients with unilateral brain injury.

1. Friederich first described the ciliated hepatic foregut cyst (CHFC) in 1857, and since then, approximately 103 cases have been reported worldwide.
2. CHFCs are rare, with a slight female predominance, and most commonly located in segments IV, V, and VIII of the liver.
3. The cyst size ranges from <1 cm to 24 cm in greatest diameter, with a median size of 3 cm, and the average age of presentation is 52 years.
4. CHFCs are typically solitary and unilocular, and have four layers: an outer fibrous rim, a layer of smooth muscle (often incomplete), subepithelial connective tissue, and a lining of ciliated, pseudo-stratified, mucin-secreting columnar epithelium.
5. The imaging appearances of CHFCs are variable and can include anechoic or hypoechoic cysts with spotty hyperechoic areas on ultrasound, non-enhancing cysts on computed tomography (CT), and hyperintense cysts on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
6. CHFCs are thought to be the result of evagination of the foregut during embryogenesis, and the term "CHFC" was coined to indicate the origin of this lesion as a detached hepatic diverticulum or detachment and migration of buds from the oesophageal and bronchial regions of the foregut.
7. Although CHFCs are generally benign, there is a risk of malignant transformation, and serial imaging may be required for patients undergoing cyst sclerosis.
8. Laparoscopic excision of CHFCs is recommended for cysts larger than 4-5 cm, symptomatic or enlarging lesions, and asymptomatic lesions with wall abnormalities on imaging or in patients with otherwise unexplained abnormal liver function tests.

1. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a catastrophic epilepsy of childhood characterized by tonic, atonic, and myoclonic seizures, as well as developmental delays and cognitive impairments.
2. The second feature required by the definition of LGS is an interictal awake electroencephalogram (EEG) pattern consisting of slow spike waves (less than 3 Hz) usually with a generalized distribution.
3. The third component of the definition of LGS is cognitive impairment involving moderate to severe mental retardation and behavioral disorders, including aggression and autistic features.
4. The typical age of onset of LGS is between 2 and 5 years, and boys are affected about 5 times more often than girls.
5. Rufinamide, a triazole derivative, was granted orphan drug status for the adjunctive treatment of LGS in the United States in 2004.
6. Rufinamide was approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treatment of LGS in children 4 years of age and older in 2011.
7. Rufinamide also blocks seizures induced by subcutaneous strychnine, bicuculline, and picrotoxin.
8. The absorption rate of rufinamide is slow, and the extent of absorption decreases as the dose is increased.
9. Early sponsored studies have provided data that rufinamide has a beneficial effect as add-on therapy for partial seizures in adolescents and adults, and a single double-blind randomized placebo-controlled trial has been published for LGS.
